creator: ksm@pobox.com
text:
The inablility to assign a url-pattern to JSP files when a servlet has a 'top 
level' general url-pattern.  

For example in web application (folder underneath webapps) called 'problem' 
exists:

problem
   |
   - templates
   |     |
   |     - test.jsp
   |
   - WEB-INF
        | 
        - web.xml
        |
        -classes
        |   | 
        |   - SnoopServlet.class
        | 
        -lib

Within the web.xml is:


   <servlet>
     <servlet-name>
       mySnoop
     </servlet-name>
     <servlet-class>
       SnoopServlet
     </servlet-class>
   </servlet>

 
   <servlet-mapping>
     <servlet-name>
       mySnoop
     </servlet-name>
     <url-pattern>
       /*
     </url-pattern>
   </servlet-mapping>


    <servlet-mapping>
        <servlet-name>
        jsp
        </servlet-name>
        <url-pattern>
        /templates/*
        </url-pattern>
    </servlet-mapping>

SnoopServlet properly is callable by:
* localhost:8080/problem/
* localhost:8080/problem/test.jsp
* localhost:8080/problem/george/test.htm

But test.jsp is never callable by 
* localhost:8080/problem/templates/test.jsp.

In fact, a directory listing is shown. 

What should occur is the test.jsp should execute.  It properly does when a url-
pattern is absolutely specific - i.e. /templates/test.jsp.  

I am using Tomcat 3.2.1 on Windows 98 or Windows 2000 and have gotten the same 
results.

creator: Larry.Isaacs@sas.com
text:
To establish a "default" servlet, the Servlet 2.2 spec requires you to use "/"
instead of "/*" as the URL pattern.
